job_title: Physical Therapist Assistant in Westwood, MA
pros: Get to make your own schedule
cons:
Getting paid by the patient
No benefits

job_title: Sales Associate in San Jose, CA
pros: Great Team company to work for and benefits are amazing.
cons: Non-for Profit so tend to pay lower and they don't get top tier talent for nurses.

pros: Employees are good people to work with.
cons:
My Supervisor was horrible and during my interview she was dishonest. I found out things after I accepted the job and left a better company. 

They change information in patient to get paid and it was just a very bad environment to work in.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Supportive managers; ethical healthcare; priority is patient care, not productivity or $$; Lots of training; work with a great assortment of clients who are all very loyal to Pathways as well
cons: Pay might seem a little less than competitors but it is worth it to have capable colleagues who are good at their jobs & a supportive honest employer

job_title: Occupational Therapist in Redwood City, CA
pros: Office gives us the resources we need to be on for field. Management is supportive. Staff are very competent and kind. Great company to work with.
cons: It can get pretty busy at times. But the schedulers are very helpful in coordinating and planning our patient case load.

pros: good place, good location, money
cons: bad people, bad attitudes and environment

pros: Benefit package is good especially for full time employees with no dependants to cover for health insurance. The staff really cares about doing a good job and this is true for the patient care staff and office workers.Middle managers work hard and  try to run the place the best they can in spite  of the Cons.
cons: Salaries have fallen behind other agencies, we're  short staffed and the biggest Con is  that upper management is arrogant and out of touch.  The executives suck up to hospitals but ignore the people who give care for the patients or worse, they fire them for speaking up. The CEO is a bully, no other word for her. Her style is lead by intimidating everybody and ridicule and blame people  rather than taking any responsibility herself  for the BIG losses the company has had. The new CMO is a bully too who's disrespectful and brags  about how much he thinks he knows and what he did at his old jobs.  The work environment is toxic and making people quit. The people producing the work get basic raises but the C Suite people earn enormous salaries that grow every year. Look them up and be shocked.

pros: I'm the kind of person who thrives knowing that my actions have meaning. That's why I joined Pathways. I need to know that my work life is spent doing something that I can look back upon with a positive sense of accomplishment. Pathways gives me that. They have competitive salaries for the marketplace (and for being a non-profit). Recent hires are bringing with them a sense of professionalism and background that is truly improving the overall functioning, with better policies, communications, and more staff training. I'm feel very hopeful of my career growth potential and professional opportunities here.
cons: As a small non-profit operating in the SF Bay Area, staff members are each doing the work of three people. (Definitely never a dull moment!) However, there is the overall feeling that the organization is in "reaction mode" (fighting fires) instead of "proactive mode" (effective planning), which can lead to frustration. A lot of decisions made are questioned and changed or reversed later--either by the originators or someone in senior management.

pros: Flexibility, somewhat  of a teamwork-driven environment where colleagues are willing to help.
cons: Micromanagement, aggressive staff,  heavily bureaucratic work environment.  Lack of available overtime.  Constant employee turnover and restructuring of management team.  Excessive socializing, discussions about what to eat for lunch, and extracurricular obligations creates much distraction on the floor.  Sales staff has zero to bare minimal training on how to assess patients for hospice eligibility (lack of medical background).  Sky high cancellation rate due to dissatisfied family members who were not impressed with the clinicians assigned to care for their loved ones. Unprofessionalism galore. Too much concern with hitting sales quota and lack of compassion for the patients and families. Keep looking.

review_title: Such a bad management that doesn't care about their employees
job_title: Registered Nurse in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Good coworkers:  office workers and clinicians are very nice, friendly, helpful and supportive
cons: Underpaid: it is well-known Pathways pays the least among hospice agencies

pros: Excellent leadership team and dedicated staff! The CEO of Pathways is a visionary leader who cares very much about all levels of staff. The executive team is positive and supportive. The staff are dedicated and compassionate from the field staff to all the support staff that make patient care happen! The company is very forward thinking and uses technology to support all employees.
cons: I have appreciated all the opportunities given to me.

pros: Good reputation, non-profit, local agency, good benefits (healthcare is free to full time employees), flexible hours, many people stay a long time, they try new ideas, opportunities to advance.
cons: All home health and hospice has become super competitive and it affects the way they have to operate.  Healthcare is changing really fast and so Pathways is changing too. I understand that it is necessary, but I don't like the pressures the new healthcare environment has created.

review_title: Stuck in their old, tired ways
pros: Free medical and dental benefits.  Some coworkers were nice.  Working from home was preferable to working in the proximity to the other people.
cons: Management needs a shake up.  Too many upper managers have been life long employees here and it shows:  New innovations are not sought out, newer employees are not communicated with, old ways rule here - don't even think of having an original idea as it will be ridiculed and shut down unceremoniously.

pros: They had free coffee and tea.
cons: Managers are allowed to yell at you in front of everyone.  My manager said negative things to me about other employees.  No coaching for performance only discipline.

job_title: Occupational Therapist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very supportive team, good benefits, helpful and caring staff, great work culture. From executive board, to administration, HR, and clinicians - very nice, caring, and competent. Not greedy and they care about the well being of patients. Very happy to be part of this team and to work with Pathways.
cons: Busy schedule, but they do provide you with many resources and tools to be efficient and help manage your case load. Everyone (including supervisors and directors) is very approachable and helpful.

pros: no pros at this place, unless you've been working here for 10-plus years.
cons: You will be treated like an outsider here, unless you can fit in with the good ol boys and girls club. They will get rid of you just like that without any written warnings, they will set you up to fail then let you go just like that.

review_title: Not a friendly place for nurses
job_title: RN Field Case Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Wages and benefits are at least average
cons: Nurses at Pathways, especially the case managers, are undervalued, unappreciated, and treated unfairly by management. It's a fact that over half of the nursing staff have left in the past year to find other jobs. Upper management continues to be insensitive to the nurses' needs, doggedly enforcing  their unseasonable productivity standards and now threatening and punishing  nurses if they have to put in overtime in order to get their job done. Nurses are exhausted  from battling with upper management and scheduling on a daily basis because it's ultimately a losing battle. Case manager nurses frequently put in 2 to 4 hours of overtime and even work on their days off but don't record it because they are afraid of censure and don't want to get fired. The nursing staff ultimately appealed to Administration asking for a chance to be listened to, but they were given empty promises and merely placated. Now nurses who express their feelings are sometimes censured or fired. The bottom line is Pathways Home Health is not a very friendly place for nurses.

pros: The coworkers and clinicians are very friendly, helpful and supportive. Competitive pay and benefits, except for health insurance.
cons: Many limitations to the health insurance coverage, especially if one has dependents to cover. Management is overtly preoccupied with image and revenue and neglects quality. There star rating from Medicare continues to decline.

pros: The largely female staff are kind, compassionate and supportive. There's been no cattiness or passive aggressive behavior but instead, strong women supporting and lifting up other women.
cons: Not a ton of flexibility. Mediocre benefits.

review_title: Great People to work with but upper management not in touch
pros: The work is amazing, your fellow workers are heartfelt and hardworking.
cons: The management can't stick with a plan. They seem to blame everyone but themselves for why things are going wrong. I have seen them get rid of great people who did wonderful work.

review_title: Great Environment friendly family like atmosphere...Great non-profit company serving the bay area for over 40 years
pros: the benefits of working for this type of company are hard to put into a few words. the people here truly care about the patient first and always strive to provide the best customer service possible.
cons: I have NO cons to report

pros: Good Mission, Good nurses and Doctors and admin staff.
cons: CFO and CEO have run Pathways into the ground. They take excessive salaries, belittle the staff, they are rude and condescending to them, them blame them for the poor performance of the agency.

pros: Original nurses, aides, and direct management are the best but are grossly overworked and underappreciated
cons: CHI (Catholic Health Initiative) bought out Pathways recently and has systematically fired Hospice doctors, senior Social Workers and long time, loyal administrative staff with no notice, just an impersonal phone call. In my opinion the previous CEO Barbara Burgess I'm sure got a big payout and threw Pathways under the bus. Sure hope there is karma.

pros: Autonomy, decent pay, steady raises, good technology
cons: High turn over in management
